Award.AwardTitle: CCSS: Collaborative Research: Towards Privacy-Preserving Mobile Crowd Sensing: A Multi-Stage Solution

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mobile devices, including smartphones and tablets, are becoming extremely prevalent nowadays. Equipped with diverse sensors, from GPS to camera, and paired with the inherent mobility of their owners, mobile devices are capable of acquiring rich information of surrounding environment. However, the wide adoption of mobile crowd sensing is largely hindered by its privacy concerns. To facilitate the functionality of each stage of mobile crowd sensing, including sensing task allocation, sensing data collection, and result aggregation, sensing devices report their location information, sensing capabilities, task preferences, and sensing results to servers that will potentially disclose their daily routings, behavior patterns and even identities. With these concerns, the overall goal of this project is to address privacy leakage issues from different stages of mobile crowd sensing. Privacy-enhanced mobile crowd sensing will attract more participants and thus accelerate the maturity of smart health care, environment monitoring, traffic surveillance, social event observation, etc. In addition, this project will also serve as a training ground for educating future decision-makers and workforce on theory and tools.

The PIs plan to develop effective and efficient privacy preservation schemes for different stages of mobile crowd sensing. It corresponds to three closely intertwined research thrusts. Thrust I explores protecting user's sensitive information, such as locations, sensing capabilities and task preferences, from the server, while still allowing it to optimally or approximately solve task allocation problems. Rather than highly computationally-intensive crypto-based techniques, privacy preservation schemes will be designed based on decomposition methods and distributed computing algorithms. Thrust II aims to provide user's location privacy in the stage of data collection. Since locations of users, who perform sensing over the same event within a certain geographic area, are highly correlated, it deteriorates user's privacy achieved individually. To address this issue, privacy preservation schemes will be developed by exploring collaborations among users. Game theories will be adopted to further analyze users' strategies and interactions. The objective of Thrust III is to protect users' sensing data privacy during the stage of data analysis. The research is featured by jointly considering the data imperfection that is caused by the limited sensing capabilities at mobile devices and even the misbehavior of lazy/malicious users. To achieve data privacy and service accuracy simultaneously, novel schemes will be developed combining efficient matrix completion methods and advanced crypto techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mobile crowd sensing arises as a new sensing paradigm based on the power of the crowd which consists of various mobile devices, such as smartphones and wearable devices. Equipped with multiple sensors, from GPS to camera, and paired with the inherent mobility of their owners, mobile devices are capable of acquiring diverse information of surrounding environment.

 

By fusing and analyzing their multi-dimensional sensing data, MCS has potential to accelerate the maturity of smart health caring, environment monitoring, traffic surveillance, social event observation, etc. Although with all these promising visions, the wide adoption of MCS is largely hindered by its privacy concerns. This project has conducted a thorough study on enhancing the privacy preservation in different stages of MCS. By leveraging the differential privacy mechanism, the PI has developed manageable privacy preservation for mobile crowdsensing users in terms of location privacy, bid privacy, and task allocation privacy. The team has validated from both theoretical and implementation perspective that the proposed light-weighted privacy preservation techniques work better than traditional crypto-based solutions in terms of efficiency, energy saving, and usability. Besides, to better provide authenticity for the MCS data, the PI has extended the research to securing the IoT-based data collection in MCS scenarios. Specifically, a new physical-layer attack, signal emulation attack in the heterogenous IoT environments, has been identified. This new attack can compromise the crowdsensing data from diverse commercial-off-the-shelf IoT devices used by MCS. The PI has proposed and evaluated different physical-layer defensive mechanisms to prevent attackers from obtaining the MCS data. The performance of MCS also highly relies on the way that data is transmitted, in which the current data traffic always exacerbates the energy consumption on both cellular service provider and MCS users. To alleviate the MCS traffic, the PI proposed a social-aware MCS data offloading scheme to alleviate the burden during the data transmission, greatly enhancing the stability of the MCS system. The PI also designed privacy-preserving data analytical approaches for large-scale MCS systems. The major challenge for current MCS data aggregation is that MCS users must submit their data to a centralized infrastructure for processing. For many applications performing data analytics, they usually require the data should be trained after the aggregation, which obviously put privacy concerns in danger. The PI has proposed distributed learning approaches to let individual MCS users train their local data and contribute to the global training results for data analytics. By only sharing the intermediate parameters of training results, the MCS data privacy has been well preserved. All the above results have been experimentally verified using real-world datafiles.

 

The developed privacy-preserving techniques in this project can greatly enhance the mobile users’ privacy when participating a diverse range of MCS applications in future wireless systems. Meanwhile, the mobile data offloading schemes can relieve the data traffic from the infrastructure to users, and further reduce the network congestion in crowded areas, which will make significant progress and generate more business opportunities in building future smart cities. The investigation on potential wireless attacks to IoT devices can also provide insight for future wireless device manufacturing. The proposed defensive mechanisms can be generally deployed in many wireless application scenarios, such as industrial IoT, smart agriculture, and smart healthcare. During this project duration, the PI has supported two female Ph.D. students, in which one of them has already graduated and become an assistant professor at Department of Computer Science, Florida State University. Under the PI’s supervision, the team has produced 16 high-quality technical papers published in highly reputable venues in research community. The team also share the technical results to a broader range of students at Binghamton University and Clemson University.
